title: Finding South Using Southern Cross Constellation
brief: Use the Southern Cross constellation to determine south direction in the southern hemisphere.
steps: Step 1: Locate the Southern Cross - 5 stars with 4 bright stars forming a tilted cross.
Step 2: Identify the two stars that make up the cross's long axis (pointer stars).
Step 3: Measure the distance between these two pointer stars.
Step 4: Extend an imaginary line from the cross 5 times this distance.
Step 5: The end of this line points toward south.
Step 6: Look down to the horizon from this point and select a landmark.
Step 7: In static situations, drive stakes in ground at night to mark direction for daylight use.
warnings: Requires clear night sky with visible stars.
No bright star marks south pole - this gives general south direction only.
